title: Members of the Global Commission, Ricardo Lagos

quotes: Ricardo Lagos served as president of Chile from 2000 to 2006.
After leaving office, Ricardo Lagos founded the Fundación Democracia y Desarrollo (Foundation for Democracy and Development) in 2006
He is also vice-chair of the Inter-American Dialogue and was UN special envoy for climate change from 2007 to 2010.
Since 2007 he has taught at the Watson Institute for International Studies at Brown University, where he is now Professor at Large.
Ricardo Lagos earned a law degree from the University of Chile in 1960
and then attended Duke University, where he received a PhD in economics in 1966.
In 1978, he returned to Chile, where he became president of the Democratic Alliance, a coalition of parties opposed to Pinochet.
In 1987, he founded the Party for Democracy (Partido por la Democracia).
He served as a Minister in the governments of both President Patricio Aylwin (1990-1994)
and President Eduardo Frei (1994-2000).

roles.title: Minister
quotes: He served as a Minister in the governments of both President Patricio Aylwin (1990-1994) and President Eduardo Frei (1994-2000).
Ricardo Lagos served as president of Chile from 2000 to 2006.
Following the military coup against President Salvador Allende, Ricardo Lagos lived in the United States and Argentina.
Following the military coup against President Salvador Allende, Ricardo Lagos lived in the United States and Argentina.

supporting_quotes: Ricardo Lagos served as president of Chile from 2000 to 2006.
After leaving office, Ricardo Lagos founded the Fundación Democracia y Desarrollo (Foundation for Democracy and Development) in 2006 and currently serves as its President.
Since 2007 he has taught at the Watson Institute for International Studies at Brown University, where he is now Professor at Large.
He is also vice-chair of the Inter-American Dialogue and was UN special envoy for climate change from 2007 to 2010.
In 1987, he founded the Party for Democracy (Partido por la Democracia).
He served as a Minister in the governments of both President Patricio Aylwin (1990-1994) and President Eduardo Frei (1994-2000).
In 1978, he returned to Chile, where he became president of the Democratic Alliance, a coalition of parties opposed to Pinochet.
He served as consultant and economist in UNESCO and the International Labor Organization.
